question:
Which Chinese traveler visited India during the reign of Harshavardhana?

SSC CGL 14/07/2023 (4th shift)
solution:
• The Chinese traveller who visited India during the reign of Harshavardhana was Hsuan Tsang (Xuanzang).
  • He came to India in the 7th century CE, around 630 CE, during the rule of Harsha.
  • Hsuan Tsang was a Buddhist monk, scholar, and pilgrim who travelled from China to India to study and collect Buddhist scriptures.
  • He spent several years in India, especially at Nalanda University, and documented detailed accounts of Indian society, politics, economy, and religious life.
  • His book, the "Si-yu-ki" (Records of the Western World), is one of the most important sources of Indian history during Harsha’s reign.

Additional Information:

  • Faxian visited India earlier, during the Gupta period (reign of Chandragupta II).
  • Etsing (I-Tsing) also visited India but after Hsuan Tsang, in the late 7th century CE.
  • Ibn Battuta was a Moroccan traveller who came to India much later, during the 14th century, in the reign of Muhammad bin Tughlaq.

question:
What was the period of Harshavardhana's reign?

SSC CGL 25/07/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• Harshavardhana ruled from 606 CE to 647 CE, making option (c) the correct answer.
  • He succeeded his brother Rajyavardhana and established his authority in North India, uniting much of it under a single ruler.
  • His capital was initially Thanesar, but he later shifted it to Kannauj for strategic and political reasons.
  • Harsha was a patron of Buddhism, though he was tolerant of other religions, and hosted the famous Kannauj Assembly attended by Hsuan Tsang.
  • His reign marked a revival of classical learning, literature, and culture, with scholars like Banabhatta (author of Harshacharita) at his court.

Additional Information:

  • Harsha wrote three Sanskrit plays: Ratnavali, Priyadarsika, and Nagananda.
  • After his death in 647 CE, his empire disintegrated, as he had no heir to succeed him.
  • He maintained diplomatic relations with China, and Hsuan Tsang’s account provides a valuable description of India during Harsha’s rule.
  • Harsha followed a secular policy, giving patronage to Hindus, Buddhists, and Jains alike.

question:
Which among the following books was NOT written by King Harshavardhana?

SSC MTS 08/05/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Amuktamalayada, as it was not written by King Harshavardhana.
  • Harshavardhana was a renowned Sanskrit playwright and scholar who authored three plays:
    • Ratnavali
    • Nagananda
    • Priyadarsika
  • These plays reflect themes of love, duty, and religious philosophy, and showcase Harsha’s literary talent.
  • Amuktamalayada, on the other hand, is a Telugu literary work composed by Krishnadevaraya, the famous ruler of the Vijayanagara Empire.

Additional Information:

  • Amuktamalayada is known for its devotional and poetic richness and is centred around Lord Ranganatha and the devotion of Andal, a Tamil Alvar saint.
  • Krishnadevaraya ruled during the 16th century, much later than Harsha.
  • Harsha ruled in the 7th century CE and promoted Sanskrit learning and Buddhist values.
  • His court included great scholars like Banabhatta, who wrote Harshacharita, Harsha’s biography.

question:
Who wrote the "Harshacharita", a biography of Harshavardhana?

SSC CHSL 17/03/2023 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The "Harshacharita" is a Sanskrit biography of Harshavardhana, written by his court poet and close associate Banabhatta.
  • Banabhatta was one of the greatest prose writers of 7th-century India and served in Harsha’s royal court.
  • Harshacharita provides a detailed account of Harsha’s ancestry, early life, conquests, administration, and personality, combining facts with literary embellishment.
  • It is considered the first historical biography in Sanskrit literature.

Additional Information:

  • Harisena was the court poet of Samudragupta and wrote the Allahabad Pillar Inscription.
  • Ravikirti was a court poet of Pulakeshin II of the Chalukya dynasty.
  • Xuan Zang (Hsuan Tsang) was a Chinese traveller who visited Harsha’s court but did not write Harshacharita.

question:
Which of the following is NOT correct regarding king Harshavardhana?

SSC CGL 02/12/2022 (2nd Shift)
option_1: Harshavardhana ruled nearly about 1400 years ago
option_2: Xuan Zang spent a lot of time at Harsha's court
option_3: Harshavardhana's court poet was Harishena
option_4: Harshacharita is a biography written on Harshavardhana
solution:
• The incorrect statement about King Harshavardhana is (c) Harshavardhana's court poet was Harishena.
  • Harishena was the court poet of Samudragupta, not Harshavardhana.
  • Harshavardhana's actual court poet was Banabhatta, who wrote the Harshacharita, a detailed biography of the king.
  • Hence, option (c) is factually incorrect and is the correct answer to this question.

Additional Information:

  • (a) is correct: Harshavardhana ruled in the 7th century CE, which is approximately 1400 years ago from today.
  • (b) is correct: The Chinese traveller Xuan Zang (Hsuan Tsang) visited India during Harsha's reign and spent time in his court.
  • (d) is correct: Harshacharita was authored by Banabhatta and is a biography of Harshavardhana written in Sanskrit prose.

question:
The Chinese Buddhist pilgrim, Xuan Zang, came to the Indian subcontinent about _________ years ago.

SSC CGL 02/12/2022 (4th Shift)
solution:
• The Chinese Buddhist pilgrim Xuan Zang (also spelled Xuanzang or Hsuan Tsang) visited the Indian subcontinent during the reign of Harshavardhana, around 630 CE.
  • As of now (2025), that visit occurred approximately 1395 years ago, which rounds off to 1400 years.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is (d) 1400.
  • Xuan Zang came to India to study Buddhist philosophy and collect sacred texts, spending many years at Nalanda University and in Harsha’s court.
  • His travel records provide valuable historical accounts of 7th-century India.

Additional Information:

  • His book, "Si-Yu-Ki" (Records of the Western Regions), details Indian geography, politics, culture, and religion during that era.
  • He journeyed through the Silk Route, passing through Central Asia before reaching India.
  • His accounts are important for reconstructing Harsha’s empire and the conditions of India during that period.

question:
Who among the following defeated Harshavardhana when he invaded the Chalukya kingdom in the Deccan?

SSC CGL 13/04/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• When Harshavardhana, the ruler of North India, tried to expand his empire into the Deccan, he was defeated by Pulakesin II, the powerful Chalukya king of Badami.
  • The battle took place near the Narmada River, which marked the boundary between the northern and southern Indian kingdoms.
  • This defeat effectively halted Harsha’s southern expansion and established the Narmada as the southern frontier of his empire.
  • Pulakesin II was a skilled military leader and a prominent ruler of the Chalukya dynasty, known for resisting northern invasions.

Additional Information:

  • Pulakesin II ruled from c. 610–642 CE, around the same time as Harshavardhana (606–647 CE).
  • The famous Aihole inscription, composed by his court poet Ravikirti, records this victory over Harsha.
  • Pulakesin II expanded the Chalukya kingdom across the Deccan region, making it a dominant southern power.
  • This encounter between Harsha and Pulakesin II is one of the rare recorded clashes between North and South Indian empires.

question:
King Shashanka, against whom Harshvardhana declared war, was a ruler of the ________ kingdom.

SSC MTS 14/10/2021 (Evening)
solution:
• King Shashanka was the ruler of the Gauda kingdom, located in present-day Bengal (West Bengal and parts of Bangladesh).
  • He was a contemporary and rival of Harshavardhana and played a major role in the political struggles of early 7th-century northern India.
  • Harshavardhana declared war against Shashanka because he was suspected of being involved in the murder of Rajyavardhana, Harsha’s elder brother.
  • Shashanka was also known for his hostility towards Buddhism, and he is believed to have cut down the Bodhi tree at Bodh Gaya.

Additional Information:

  • The Gauda kingdom under Shashanka was a significant power in eastern India during the 7th century CE.
  • Though Harsha launched a campaign against Shashanka, he could not decisively defeat him as Shashanka died before any major conquest.
  • The rivalry between Harsha and Shashanka reflects the fragmented and competitive political landscape of post-Gupta northern India.
  • After Shashanka’s death, Harsha consolidated his power over Magadha and surrounding regions.

question:
Pushyabhuti, who ruled from Thaneswar, was the founder of _______ dynasty.

SSC CGL 17/08/2021 (Morning)
solution:
• Pushyabhuti, who ruled from Thaneswar (in present-day Haryana), was the founder of the Vardhana dynasty.
  • The Vardhana dynasty gained prominence in North India in the 6th and 7th centuries CE, with Harshavardhana being its most notable ruler.
  • Pushyabhuti laid the foundation, and his descendants, including Prabhakaravardhana, expanded the kingdom.
  • Under Harshavardhana, the dynasty reached its greatest territorial extent, uniting much of northern India.

Additional Information:

  • The Chera, Pandya, and Chalukya dynasties were powerful in South India.
    • Chera: Kerala and western Tamil Nadu.
    • Pandya: Southern Tamil Nadu.
    • Chalukya: Deccan region, especially Karnataka.
  • The Vardhana dynasty is also referred to as the Pushyabhuti dynasty, after its founder.

question:
King Harshavardhan ascended the throne of Thaneshwar and Kannauj on the death of his brother, _________.

SSC CGL 04/03/2020 (Morning)
solution:
• King Harshavardhana ascended the throne of Thaneswar and Kannauj after the death of his elder brother, Rajyavardhana.
  • Rajyavardhana was the ruler of Thaneswar and had gone to avenge his sister’s husband's murder but was killed treacherously by King Shashanka of Gauda.
  • After his death, Harsha took charge of the kingdom and soon expanded his influence across much of North India.
  • Harsha proved to be a strong and capable ruler, leading the Vardhana dynasty to prominence.

Additional Information:

  • Rajyavardhana and Harsha were sons of Prabhakaravardhana, a ruler of the Pushyabhuti (Vardhana) dynasty.
  • Harsha shifted his capital from Thaneswar to Kannauj, making it a major political and cultural centre.
  • Harsha’s rule is known for peace, learning, and religious tolerance, as well as patronage of arts and literature.

question:
In the Chola administration, _________ was the assembly in the villages which were inhabited predominantly by the Brahmanas.

SSC CGL 14/07/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• In the Chola administration, the "Sabha" was the village assembly found in settlements predominantly inhabited by Brahmanas.
  • These Brahmana villages were called agraharas, and the sabha functioned as an autonomous administrative body.
  • The Sabha had various committees (known as variams) responsible for handling different aspects like irrigation, temples, justice, and tax collection.
  • Members of the Sabha were typically learned Brahmanas, and they were selected based on strict qualifications like age, knowledge of the Vedas, and land ownership.

Additional Information:

  • Ur was the general village assembly for non-Brahmana villages.
  • Nagaram referred to the assembly or guild in urban areas and trading centres, often consisting of merchants.
  • Khilya is not a term associated with Chola administration and is not relevant to this context.
  • The Chola system is considered one of the most well-organised local self-governance models in Indian history.

question:
Sabha and Ur, two kinds of village assemblies are referred to in which of the following dynasties?

SSC CGL 20/07/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• The terms "Sabha" and "Ur" refer to two types of village assemblies during the rule of the Chola dynasty in South India.
  • The Cholas (9th–13th century CE) developed one of the most sophisticated local self-government systems in Indian history.
  • "Sabha" was the assembly in Brahmana-dominated villages, often called Agraharas, where learned Brahmins administered village affairs through structured committees (variams).
  • "Ur" referred to the general assembly of villages inhabited by non-Brahmana populations.
  • These assemblies managed taxes, irrigation, temples, roads, justice, and village welfare, showcasing the decentralised governance system of the Cholas.

Additional Information:

  • Inscriptions like the Uttaramerur inscription provide detailed records of how these assemblies functioned.
  • The Rashtrakutas, Gurjara Pratiharas, and Chalukyas did not have such an elaborate village assembly system as documented in Chola rule.
  • The Chola model is often studied as an early form of grassroots democratic governance in ancient India.

question:
"Brahmadeya", a type of land during the Chola Period, was the __________.

SSC MTS 10/05/2023
option_1: land gifted to Brahmans
option_2: land of non-Brahmana peasant proprietors
option_3: land gifted to temples
option_4: land of royal person
solution:
• During the Chola period, "Brahmadeya" referred to land gifted to Brahmanas.
  • These were often tax-free grants made by kings or local chiefs to individual Brahmins or groups of Brahmins.
  • Such lands were usually part of agraharas, where Brahmins settled and carried out religious and educational duties.
  • The objective was to promote Brahmanical learning and religious rituals, and it also helped in expanding agricultural activity in newly cleared areas.

Additional Information:

  • The Chola rulers made many land grants, including:
    • Devadana or Devadaya: Land gifted to temples.
    • Vellanvagai: Land cultivated by non-Brahmana peasant proprietors.
    • Rajakaniya: Land under direct royal ownership.
  • Brahmadeya lands played a significant role in the development of village administration and local economy under Chola rule.

question:
The Airavatesvara Temple in Tamil Nadu was built by _________.

SSC MTS 14/06/2023 (Afternoon)
option_3: Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh II
solution:
• The Airavatesvara Temple is located in Darasuram, near Kumbakonam in Tamil Nadu.
  • It was built by Rajaraja Chola II in the 12th century CE, specifically around 1146–1173 CE.
  • The temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva, who is worshipped here as Airavatesvara (the Lord of Airavata, Indra’s white elephant).
  • This temple is part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site under the group titled "Great Living Chola Temples".

Additional Information:

  • Rajaraja Chola I (option b) built the famous Brihadeshwara Temple at Thanjavur.
  • Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh II (option c) was a ruler of Amber/Jaipur and is known for building Jantar Mantars.
  • Maharaja Pratap Singh (option d) was a ruler of Thanjavur Maratha kingdom, much later than the Cholas.
  • The Airavatesvara Temple is known for its fine stone carvings, chariot-shaped sanctum, and inscriptions describing donations and temple rituals.

question:
The term "Vetti" in Chola empire is related to __________.

SSC MTS 14/06/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• In the Chola Empire, the term "Vetti" referred to a system of forced labour.
  • It was a form of unpaid work demanded by the state from the peasants, especially from those who were landless or belonged to lower castes.
  • Vetti was often used for public works, including irrigation, road construction, and temple maintenance.
  • This labour was typically compulsory and not compensated, making it exploitative in nature.

Additional Information:

  • The Chola administration was otherwise highly structured, with village assemblies and committees.
  • While some taxes were paid in kind or cash, Vetti was a non-monetary obligation imposed on certain sections of society.
  • Similar forced labour systems existed in other empires too but under different names.

question:
Rajaraja I, considered the most powerful Chola ruler, became king in ________.

SSC CHSL 15/03/2023 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• Rajaraja I, regarded as the most powerful and influential ruler of the Chola dynasty, ascended the throne in 985 CE.
  • His reign marked the beginning of Chola imperial expansion, both in mainland India and overseas (Sri Lanka and Southeast Asia).
  • He consolidated the Chola kingdom and launched successful military campaigns against the Pandyas, Cheras, and the Sinhala kingdom.
  • Rajaraja I is also known for commissioning the Brihadeshwara Temple in Thanjavur, a UNESCO World Heritage site.

Additional Information:

  • Rajaraja I ruled from 985 CE to 1014 CE.
  • He established a strong navy, which played a major role in overseas expeditions.
  • His reign laid the foundation for the golden age of the Cholas, continued by his son Rajendra Chola I.
  • He also implemented efficient administrative reforms, including land surveys and revenue collection.

question:
Which of the following towns was built by the ruler Vijayalaya in Kaveri delta?

SSC CGL 01/12/2022 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (d) Thanjavur.
  • Vijayalaya Chola, the founder of the Chola dynasty’s imperial line, captured Thanjavur in the 9th century CE and made it the capital of the emerging Chola power.
  • Located in the Kaveri delta, Thanjavur became a political, cultural, and religious centre under the Cholas.
  • The city later flourished under Rajaraja I, who built the magnificent Brihadeshwara Temple there.

Additional Information:

  • Tiruchirappalli, Tiruppur, and Madurai are also major cities in Tamil Nadu but were not established by Vijayalaya.
  • Madurai was historically associated with the Pandya dynasty.
  • The Kaveri delta provided fertile lands and strategic advantages, making Thanjavur an ideal centre for Chola administration.

question:
Sultan Mahmud of Ghazni was a contemporary of which Chola king?

SSC CGL 02/12/2022 (4th Shift)
solution:
• Sultan Mahmud of Ghazni (ruled 997–1030 CE) was a contemporary of Rajendra Chola I, who ruled from 1014 to 1044 CE.
  • Mahmud of Ghazni is known for his 17 invasions of India, targeting northern kingdoms and temples for wealth.
  • During the same period in South India, Rajendra I was expanding the Chola Empire with military expeditions, including the famous campaign to the Ganges and overseas conquests to Southeast Asia.
  • Although they ruled in different parts of the subcontinent, their reigns overlapped during the early 11th century CE.

Additional Information:

  • Rajaraja I (985–1014 CE), Rajendra’s father, ruled just before Mahmud’s major campaigns began.
  • Rajadhiraja I and Rajendra II ruled after Mahmud's death.
  • There is no direct interaction recorded between Mahmud of Ghazni and the Cholas, as Mahmud focused on northern India, while the Cholas dominated the south and east.

question:
In the early eleventh century, the Chola king Rajendra I built a Shiva temple and filled it with a Sun-pedestal seized from the ___________.

SSC CGL 03/12/2022 (1st Shift)
solution:
• In the early 11th century, Rajendra Chola I undertook military campaigns against several kingdoms, including the Chalukyas of the Deccan.
  • After defeating the Chalukyas, he brought back several war trophies, one of which was a Sun-pedestal (Surya Peetha).
  • He placed this Sun-pedestal in a Shiva temple that he built to commemorate his victories.
  • This act symbolised not only military dominance but also religious-political assertion, integrating the spoils of war into temple culture.

Additional Information:

  • Rajendra I ruled from 1014 to 1044 CE, and continued the imperial ambitions of his father Rajaraja I.
  • He is best known for his northern expedition to the Ganges and his naval expeditions to Southeast Asia.
  • The Chalukyas referred to here are the Western Chalukyas, also known as the Later Chalukyas, centred at Kalyani.

question:
Some important administrative posts were hereditary during the Rashtrakuta and Chola dynasties. The post 'nagara-shreshthi' meant?

SSC CGL 03/12/2022 (2nd Shift)
option_1: Leader of the merchant caravans
option_2: Merchant of the city
solution:
• The term "nagara-shreshthi" refers to the chief merchant or head of the merchant community in a city.
  • During the Rashtrakuta and Chola dynasties, many administrative and commercial positions, including nagara-shreshthi, were hereditary.
  • The nagara-shreshthi held considerable influence over urban trade, guild affairs, and sometimes even local administration.
  • He was responsible for overseeing city-based trade activities, representing merchant interests, and ensuring smooth commercial operations.

Additional Information:

  • The term is derived from:
    • "nagara" = city
    • "shreshthi" = chief or head (especially of a guild or group)
  • Other important commercial titles included:
    • Sarthavaha – leader of merchant caravans
    • Prathama-kulika – chief artisan
    • Setthi or Sheth – wealthy banker/merchant
  • These posts indicate the importance of trade and guilds in early medieval Indian urban society.

question:
Who among the following belonged to the ancient chiefly family of the Cholas from Uraiyur, captured the Kaveri delta from the Muttaraiyar in the middle of the ninth century?

SSC CGL 06/12/2022 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Vijayalaya.
  • Vijayalaya Chola was the founder of the imperial Chola dynasty in the 9th century CE.
  • He belonged to the ancient chiefly family of the Cholas from Uraiyur, the early Chola capital.
  • Around 850 CE, he captured the Kaveri delta region from the Muttaraiyar, a local ruling dynasty supported by the Pallavas.
  • After this victory, he established his capital at Thanjavur, marking the rise of the Cholas as a dominant power in South India.

Additional Information:

  • The Muttaraiyar were feudal lords under the Pallavas, and their defeat marked the decline of Pallava influence in the region.
  • Gandaraditya, Parantaka I, and Aditya I were later rulers in the Chola dynasty.
    • Aditya I succeeded Vijayalaya and continued the expansion of the empire.
    • Parantaka I was known for his military victories, especially against the Pandyas.
    • Gandaraditya was a less militaristic ruler and more inclined towards religion and literature.

question:
Rajaraja I and Rajendra I belonged to the _________ dynasty.

SSC CGL 07/12/2022 (1st Shift)
solution:
• Rajaraja I and his son Rajendra I were rulers of the Chola dynasty, one of the most powerful and culturally rich dynasties in South Indian history.
  • Rajaraja I ruled from 985 CE to 1014 CE and laid the foundation of the Chola Empire’s imperial expansion.
  • His son Rajendra I succeeded him and ruled from 1014 CE to 1044 CE, further expanding the empire to North India and Southeast Asia.
  • Both kings are known for their military conquests, efficient administration, naval power, and patronage of art and architecture.

Additional Information:

  • Rajaraja I built the famous Brihadeshwara Temple at Thanjavur.
  • Rajendra I led successful expeditions to the Ganges region and even launched naval campaigns to Southeast Asia.
  • Their reigns represent the golden age of Chola power.
  • The other options:
    • Pallava: Known for rulers like Mahendravarman and Narasimhavarman.
    • Pandya: A Tamil dynasty based in Madurai.
    • Chalukya: Ruled parts of Deccan (Karnataka and Maharashtra).

question:
Which of the following Chola rulers built a temple for goddess Nishumbhasudini?

SSC CGL 07/12/2022 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (c) Vijayalaya.
  • Vijayalaya Chola, the founder of the imperial Chola dynasty, captured Thanjavur from the Muttaraiyars in the mid-9th century CE.
  • After this victory, he built a temple dedicated to goddess Nishumbhasudini, a fierce form of Durga, at Thanjavur.
  • This act symbolised both his military triumph and his devotion to the goddess, and it helped consolidate his political legitimacy.

Additional Information:

  • The temple built by Vijayalaya was an important early religious structure that demonstrated royal patronage to Shaktism.
  • Nishumbhasudini is another name for Durga, particularly associated with her act of slaying the demon Nishumbha.
  • Other rulers:
    • Aditya I was Vijayalaya's son who further expanded the Chola territory.
    • Rajendra II ruled later in the 11th century CE.
    • Rajaraja I built the famous Brihadeshwara Temple for Lord Shiva.

question:
Which of the following towns was grown as a temple town during the Chola dynasty?

SSC CGL 08/12/2022 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (a) Bhillasvamin.
  • Bhillasvamin was a town that developed as a temple town during the Chola dynasty.
  • In medieval South India, temple towns were central to religious, economic, and social life. They served as hubs of pilgrimage, trade, and education.
  • Such towns often developed around large temples, which were endowed by kings and served as major employers and landowners.

Additional Information:

  • Bhillasvamin is believed to be associated with modern-day Bilsad in Uttar Pradesh, where inscriptions suggest temple-based urban growth.
  • Chola kings, especially Rajaraja I and Rajendra I, supported large-scale temple construction, leading to the development of temple towns like:
    • Thanjavur (with Brihadeshwara Temple),
    • Gangaikonda Cholapuram, and
    • others across the Kaveri delta.
  • The other options:
    • Ajmer was associated with the Chahamanas (Chauhans).
    • Ahmedabad was founded much later by Ahmad Shah I in the 15th century.
    • Ahmednagar was established in the 15th century by Malik Ahmad Nizam Shah.

question:
Which of the following territories to the south and north were made part of the Chola kingdom by the successors of the ruler Vijayalaya?

SSC CGL 09/12/2022 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Pandyan and Pallava.
  • Vijayalaya Chola, founder of the imperial Chola dynasty, captured Thanjavur in the mid-9th century.
  • His successors, especially Aditya I and Parantaka I, expanded the Chola kingdom significantly.
    • They defeated the Pallavas (to the north) and annexed their capital Kanchipuram.
    • They also waged successful campaigns against the Pandyas (to the south) and incorporated their territory.
  • This territorial expansion laid the foundation for the Cholas’ dominance in South India.

Additional Information:

  • The Pallava dynasty, ruling from Kanchipuram, was a major rival of the early Cholas in northern Tamil Nadu.
  • The Pandya dynasty, based in Madurai, controlled southern Tamil Nadu and was another strong southern power.
  • Aditya I defeated Aparajita Pallava, ending Pallava rule.
  • Later rulers like Rajaraja I and Rajendra I expanded the empire even further, including parts of Sri Lanka and Southeast Asia.

question:
Which dynasty bronze statues were made using the "lost wax" technique?

SSC CGL 12/12/2022 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (a) Chola.
  • The Chola dynasty (9th to 13th century CE) is renowned for its exquisite bronze sculptures, especially of Hindu deities like Nataraja (dancing Shiva), Parvati, Vishnu, and others.
  • These bronze idols were made using the "lost wax technique" (also known as cire-perdue), an ancient method of metal casting.
  • This process involved creating a wax model, covering it with clay, then heating it so that the wax melted away, leaving a mould into which molten metal was poured.

Additional Information:

  • The Chola bronzes are noted for their graceful proportions, detailed ornamentation, and lifelike expression.
  • These sculptures were mainly used in temples and religious processions and reflected the Cholas’ devotion to Shaivism and Vaishnavism.
  • The Pandyas, Chalukyas, and Palas also supported art, but the finest lost wax bronze casting tradition is associated with the Cholas.
  • Chola bronzes are now considered masterpieces of Indian classical art and are housed in major museums worldwide.

question:
Puhar or Kaveripattinam, was the port of which of the following dynasty?

SSC CGL 13/12/2022 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Cholas.
  • Puhar, also known as Kaveripattinam, was an important ancient port city of the Chola dynasty.
  • It was located near the mouth of the Kaveri River on the eastern coast of Tamil Nadu.
  • Puhar served as a major trade centre, connecting the Cholas to Southeast Asia, Sri Lanka, and even Roman territories through maritime routes.

Additional Information:

  • Puhar is mentioned in ancient Tamil literature like the Silappatikaram, where it is portrayed as a prosperous and vibrant port city.
  • The city had separate zones for merchants, foreigners, artisans, and nobles, indicating its urban planning and commercial importance.
  • The port declined, possibly due to sea erosion or floods, and lost prominence in later centuries.
  • The Chera and Pandya dynasties also had port towns like Muziris (Chera) and Korkai (Pandya), but Puhar was specifically associated with the Cholas.

question:
Rajendra I was the son of which of the following Chola kings?

Higher Secondary 02/08/2022 (Shift - 2)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Rajaraja I.
  • Rajendra Chola I was the son and successor of Rajaraja Chola I, the great emperor who laid the foundation of the Chola Empire’s imperial expansion.
  • Rajendra I ruled from 1014 CE to 1044 CE and further expanded the empire beyond the achievements of his father.
  • He is best known for:
    • The Gangaikonda Ganga expedition, where he brought water from the Ganges to the south.
    • Naval expeditions to Sri Lanka, the Maldives, and Southeast Asia, demonstrating Chola maritime power.
    • Establishing a new capital named Gangaikonda Cholapuram.

Additional Information:

  • Virarajendra, Vijayalaya, and Gandaraditya were also Chola rulers but not Rajendra I's father:
    • Virarajendra was Rajendra I’s son.
    • Vijayalaya was the founder of the imperial Chola dynasty.
    • Gandaraditya was a Chola ruler before Rajaraja I.

question:
Brihadeshwara temple at Thanjavur is one of the largest temples in India and is an example of Dravidian architecture during the _________ period.

SSC MTS 19/07/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Chola.
  • The Brihadeshwara Temple, also known as Peruvudaiyar Kovil, is located in Thanjavur, Tamil Nadu, and is one of the largest and most magnificent temples in India.
  • It was constructed by Rajaraja Chola I around 1010 CE, during the height of the Chola dynasty.
  • The temple is a brilliant example of Dravidian architecture, showcasing grand vimanas (temple towers), pillared halls, intricate sculptures, and murals.

Additional Information:

  • The Brihadeshwara Temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva and is part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site group known as the "Great Living Chola Temples".
  • Its towering vimana (temple tower) is about 66 metres (216 feet) high, making it one of the tallest of its kind in India.
  • The temple was built using granite, despite no known sources of granite nearby—indicating advanced engineering and logistics.
  • The Chera, Pandya, and Hoysala dynasties also supported temple construction, but this temple is specifically associated with the Cholas.

question:
Who among the following was the author of the play 'Mrichchhakatika'?

SSC CGL 14/07/2023 (2nd shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (c) Shudraka.
  • The play "Mrichchhakatika" (meaning The Little Clay Cart) was written by the ancient Indian playwright Shudraka.
  • It is a ten-act Sanskrit drama that deals with themes like love, politics, social injustice, and class conflict.
  • The story revolves around Charudatta, a poor but noble Brahmin, and Vasantasena, a rich courtesan.

Additional Information:

  • The play is notable for its realistic portrayal of society, use of common people as characters, and complex plot.
  • Though little is known about Shudraka, tradition holds that he was a wise and learned king.
  • Other options:
    • Kalidasa: Famous for Abhijnanasakuntalam, Meghaduta, Raghuvamsa.
    • Amarasimha: Known for his Sanskrit lexicon Amarakosha.
    • Bhasa: An earlier dramatist known for plays like Svapnavasavadattam.

question:
The Ashtadhyayi of Panini is a renowned work on __________.

SSC CGL 18/07/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (d) Sanskrit Grammar.
  • The "Ashtadhyayi" is a renowned treatise on Sanskrit grammar written by the ancient scholar Panini.
  • Composed around the 5th–6th century BCE, it consists of eight chapters (Ashta = eight, Adhyayi = chapters), hence the name Ashtadhyayi.
  • It is a systematic and scientific work that defines nearly 4,000 grammatical rules governing classical Sanskrit.

Additional Information:

  • Panini’s Ashtadhyayi is considered the foundational text of linguistic analysis, not just in India but globally.
  • His work includes concepts like roots, suffixes, prefixes, and phonetics, and uses a notation system similar to modern computer programming syntax.
  • The Ashtadhyayi influenced later scholars like Patanjali, who wrote the Mahabhashya, a commentary on Panini’s work.
  • Other options:
    • Mauryan polity is discussed in works like Arthashastra (by Kautilya).
    • Gupta administration is known through inscriptions and accounts of travellers.
    • Medicine is covered in texts like the Charaka Samhita and Sushruta Samhita.

question:
Who among the following was the author of 'Indica', an account of India under the reign of the Maurya dynasty?

SSC CGL 19/07/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (d) Megasthenes.
  • Megasthenes was a Greek ambassador sent by Seleucus I Nicator to the court of Chandragupta Maurya, the founder of the Maurya Empire.
  • He authored the book ‘Indica’, which is one of the earliest foreign accounts of India during the Mauryan period.
  • Though the original text is lost, its content survives through quotations and references in the works of later writers like Strabo, Arrian, and Diodorus Siculus.

Additional Information:

  • ‘Indica’ provides valuable information about:
    • The administration, society, economy, and geography of India during Chandragupta’s reign.
    • The capital Pataliputra, its layout, fortifications, and governance.
    • Indian customs, castes, and even wildlife.
  • The other options:
    • Strabo, Pliny, and Diodorus Siculus were classical authors who referenced Megasthenes’ Indica, but did not write it themselves.

question:
"Amatya” in the Saptang Theory of Kautilya denotes which of the following?

SSC CGL 19/07/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Minister and Officials.
  • In Kautilya’s Saptang Theory (Theory of Seven Limbs of the State), as described in the Arthashastra, the state is compared to a living organism with seven essential elements (angās).
  • The term “Amatya” refers to ministers and officials who assist the king in administration and governance.

The Seven Elements (Saptanga) of the State are:

  1. Swami – The King (sovereign)
  2. Amatya – Ministers and Officials
  3. Janapada – Territory and Population
  4. Durga – Fortified Capital (Fort)
  5. Kosha – Treasury
  6. Danda – Army or Force
  7. Mitra – Ally or Friend

Additional Information:

  • Kautilya (Chanakya) was the author of the Arthashastra, an ancient Indian treatise on statecraft, economic policy, and military strategy.
  • The Amatya was expected to be well-versed in administration, honest, loyal, and skilled in advising the king.
  • The Saptanga Theory emphasizes that all seven limbs must be strong and well-functioning for the state to prosper.

question:
Who among the following was the most famous Shaka ruler, who got the Sudarshana Lake in Kathiawar renovated?

SSC CGL 20/07/2023 (2nd shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (a) Rudradaman I.
  • Rudradaman I was the most prominent ruler of the Western Shaka (Western Kshatrapa) dynasty, who ruled during the 2nd century CE.
  • He is best known for getting the Sudarshana Lake in the Kathiawar region (modern-day Gujarat) renovated after it was damaged by floods.
  • This renovation is recorded in the Junagadh rock inscription, which is one of the earliest examples of inscriptions in Sanskrit.

Additional Information:

  • Sudarshana Lake was originally constructed during the Mauryan period, possibly under Chandragupta Maurya and later maintained by Ashoka.
  • Rudradaman’s renovation of the lake reflects his interest in public welfare and irrigation.
  • Other options:
    • Maues was the first Indo-Scythian (Shaka) ruler in India but not known for this lake.
    • Rudrasimha III was the last known ruler of the Western Kshatrapas.
    • Chashtana was an earlier ruler and the grandfather of Rudradaman I.

question:
Who was the last king of the Shunga dynasty?

SSC CGL 24/07/2023 (2nd shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (d) Devabhuti.
  • Devabhuti was the last ruler of the Shunga dynasty, which succeeded the Maurya Empire in North India.
  • He ruled during the 1st century BCE and was assassinated by his minister Vasudeva Kanva, who then established the Kanva dynasty.
  • The Shunga dynasty was founded by Pushyamitra Shunga, a former general of the Mauryan Empire, who overthrew the last Mauryan ruler Brihadratha.

Additional Information:

  • The Shunga dynasty ruled from around 185 BCE to 73 BCE.
  • Devabhuti’s weak leadership allowed internal conspiracies and led to the downfall of the dynasty.
  • Other options:
    • Pushyamitra: The founder and first king of the Shunga dynasty.
    • Bhavabhuti: Not a king—he was a Sanskrit scholar and dramatist from a later period.
    • Shashanka: A 7th-century CE ruler of Gauda (Bengal), not related to the Shungas.

question:
Of which of the following Pratihara kings was Rajashekhara, the famous poet and dramatist, the court poet?

SSC CGL 25/07/2023 (2nd shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (d) Mahendrapala.
  • Rajashekhara, a renowned Sanskrit poet, dramatist, and literary critic, served as the court poet of Mahendrapala I, a ruler of the Gurjara-Pratihara dynasty.
  • Rajashekhara flourished during the late 9th and early 10th centuries CE, and his works reflect the glory and culture of the Pratihara court.

Key Contributions of Rajashekhara:

  • He authored several notable works in Sanskrit and Prakrit, including:
    • Karpuramanjari – a famous Prakrit drama.
    • Kavya-mimamsa – a treatise on poetics, offering guidance on how to write and appreciate poetry.
    • Balaramayana – a version of the Ramayana.
  • He is also known for being one of the few classical poets who mentioned his wife Avantisundari, acknowledging her literary talents.

Additional Information:

  • Mahendrapala I ruled during the 9th century CE, and his reign marked the cultural zenith of the Gurjara-Pratiharas.
  • Other options:
    • Rajapala: A later Pratihara ruler, under whom the dynasty weakened.
    • Devapala: A Pala dynasty ruler, not a Pratihara.
    • Ramabhadra: An earlier and less significant Pratihara king.

question:
Who were the first to make land grants to Brahmins?

Graduate Level 30/06/2023 (Shift - 1)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Satavahanas.
  • The Satavahanas, who ruled in the Deccan region (circa 1st century BCE to 3rd century CE), were the first known dynasty in India to make land grants to Brahmins.
  • These land grants were often tax-free (agrahara grants) and given to individual Brahmins or groups, usually for religious and educational purposes.
  • The grants were inscribed on copper plates or stones, and this practice became widespread in later Indian dynasties.

Additional Information:

  • These early land grants helped establish Brahmana settlements, promote Brahmanical culture, and spread agricultural expansion.
  • The Satavahanas set the precedent that was followed by later dynasties like the Guptas, Vakatakas, and Cholas.
  • Other options:
    • Sakas, Kushans, and Guptas also made land grants, but not before the Satavahanas.
    • The Guptas (4th–6th century CE) institutionalised the practice further, but were chronologically later.

question:
The Temple at Khajuraho were built during which dynasty?

SSC MTS 02/05/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Chandella dynasty.
  • The Khajuraho temples, located in Madhya Pradesh, were built by the Chandella rulers between the 10th and 12th centuries CE.
  • These temples are renowned for their Nagara-style architecture and intricately carved sculptures, especially the famous erotic art panels.

Additional Information:

  • The most notable Chandella kings involved in temple construction were Yashovarman and Dhanga.
  • Originally, there were about 85 temples at Khajuraho, but only around 20–25 have survived.
  • The temples are dedicated to Hindu deities like Shiva, Vishnu, and also Jain Tirthankaras.
  • The Khajuraho Group of Monuments is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
  • Other options:
    • Maurya dynasty: Known for Emperor Ashoka and early Buddhist monuments.
    • Nanda dynasty: Preceded the Mauryas; no known temple architecture.
    • Vijayanagara dynasty: Flourished in South India during the 14th–16th centuries CE, long after Khajuraho.

question:
Mahabalipuram Monuments were built in _______ dynasty architecture.

SSC MTS 03/05/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Pallava.
  • The monuments at Mahabalipuram (also known as Mamallapuram) were built during the reign of the Pallava dynasty, particularly under the rule of Narasimhavarman I (also known as Mamalla, 7th century CE).
  • These monuments showcase early Dravidian architecture and include rock-cut caves, monolithic rathas (chariots), open-air reliefs, and structural temples.

Key Features:

  • The Five Rathas (Pancha Rathas), Arjuna’s Penance (a massive open-air rock relief), and the Shore Temple are some of the most notable structures.
  • The architectural style reflects a transition from rock-cut to structural temple architecture in South India.
  • These monuments are now part of a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Additional Information:

  • Chandella dynasty: Known for the Khajuraho temples in Madhya Pradesh.
  • Pali: Not a dynasty; it's a language used in Buddhist texts.
  • Gupta dynasty: Famous for classical art and architecture in North India, but not related to Mahabalipuram.

question:
During the reign of which of the following Pallavas, Hiuen Tsang visited the Pallava capital Kanchi?

SSC MTS 08/05/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• The correct answer is (a) Narasimhavarman I.
  • The famous Chinese traveller and Buddhist monk Hiuen Tsang (Xuanzang) visited India during the 7th century CE, and during his travels, he visited the Pallava capital Kanchi (Kanchipuram).
  • At that time, Narasimhavarman I was the ruling monarch of the Pallava dynasty.
  • Narasimhavarman I (reigned c. 630–668 CE) was also known by the title Mamalla, after whom Mamallapuram (Mahabalipuram) is named.

Additional Information:

  • Narasimhavarman I is renowned for:
    • Defeating Pulakesin II of the Chalukyas in the famous Battle of Vatapi.
    • Commissioning many rock-cut monuments at Mamallapuram.
    • Patronising art, architecture, and Buddhism, which attracted scholars like Hiuen Tsang.
  • Hiuen Tsang described Kanchi as a great centre of learning and religion, especially for both Hindus and Buddhists.
  • Other options:
    • Narasimhavarman II (Rajasimha): Later Pallava king known for building the Shore Temple.
    • Mahendravarman I: Predecessor of Narasimhavarman I and a patron of art and Jainism/Buddhism.
    • Mahendravarman II: Briefly ruled and was less prominent historically.

question:
The most important ruler of the Satavahanas was _________.

SSC MTS 08/05/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Gautamiputra Shri Satakarni.
  • He is considered the most important and powerful ruler of the Satavahana dynasty, which ruled parts of central and southern India during the early centuries CE.
  • His reign is placed around the 1st–2nd century CE.

Major Achievements of Gautamiputra Shri Satakarni:

  • He successfully defeated the Western Kshatrapas (Shakas), including Nahapana, restoring Satavahana power in western India.
  • He extended the Satavahana empire from the Narmada River in the north to the Krishna River in the south.
  • His achievements are recorded in the Nasik inscription by his mother Gautami Balashri, which is a key historical source.

Additional Information:

  • Simuka was the founder of the Satavahana dynasty.
  • Vasistha Putra Pulumavi was the son and successor of Gautamiputra Shri Satakarni.
  • Pulumavi IV was a later ruler and is not as prominent as Gautamiputra.

question:
The capital of Sangam kingdom 'Pandyas' was __________.

SSC MTS 09/05/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The correct answer is (d) Madurai.
  • Madurai was the capital city of the Pandya kingdom during the Sangam age in ancient South India.
  • It served as the cultural and political centre of the Pandyas and was famous for its Sangams — gatherings of Tamil poets and scholars.
  • The city was associated with the Third Sangam, which produced a vast body of early Tamil literature.

Additional Information:

  • The Meenakshi Temple in Madurai, though built later, reflects the city's religious and architectural importance.
  • The Pandyas were one of the three major Tamil dynasties (alongside the Cholas and Cheras) during the Sangam period.
  • Other options:
    • Thiruvarur was associated with the Cholas.
    • Kaveripattinam was an important port of the Chola dynasty.
    • Nagapattinam was also a Chola port town but not linked to the Pandyas as a capital.

question:
The Rampurva bull that was part of a Mauryan pillar found in Rampurwa, Bihar is now placed at _________.

SSC MTS 09/05/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• The correct answer is (d) Rashtrapati Bhawan.
  • The Rampurva bull capital, which was part of a Mauryan pillar, was discovered at Rampurva in West Champaran, Bihar.
  • This polished sandstone bull sculpture, believed to have been commissioned by Emperor Ashoka, is now displayed at the Rashtrapati Bhawan (President’s House) in New Delhi.

Additional Information:

  • The Rampurva bull is an example of Mauryan art, known for its high degree of polish, realism, and symbolism.
  • It was originally placed on top of an Ashokan pillar, which often carried edicts of Ashoka promoting Dhamma (moral law).
  • The Mauryan pillars typically feature animal capitals like lions, bulls, and elephants, symbolising power and dharma.
  • Other options:
    • Pradhan Mantri Bhavan is the Prime Minister's residence.
    • Sansad refers to the Indian Parliament House.
    • Rajpath is the ceremonial boulevard (now renamed as Kartavya Path).

question:
Who among the following was the last Pallava king?

SSC MTS 11/05/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Aparajitavarman.
  • Aparajitavarman was the last ruler of the Pallava dynasty, which had ruled parts of Tamil Nadu from the 3rd century CE to the 9th century CE.
  • He ruled during the late 9th century CE, and his reign came to an end when he was defeated and killed by Aditya I, the Chola king.
  • This marked the final decline and end of Pallava rule, as the Cholas rose to power and replaced them as the dominant dynasty in the Tamil region.

Additional Information:

  • Mahendravarman I (option a): Early Pallava ruler known for supporting art and building cave temples.
  • Narasimhavarman I (option c): One of the greatest Pallava kings, known for defeating the Chalukyas and building Mahabalipuram.
  • Simhavishnu (option d): Re-established Pallava power and father of Mahendravarman I.

question:
Who among the following was Shaka ruler in India (AD 130-150)?

SSC MTS 15/05/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• The correct answer is (c) Rudradaman.
  • Rudradaman I was a powerful ruler of the Western Shaka (Kshatrapa) dynasty, who ruled around 130–150 CE.
  • He is especially known for the Junagadh rock inscription, which records his achievements and the repair of the Sudarshana Lake in Gujarat.
  • Rudradaman was among the first Indian rulers to issue inscriptions in classical Sanskrit, showing the cultural shift in administration.

Additional Information:

  • Rudradaman was involved in military campaigns and defeated the Satavahanas multiple times, although he did not annex their territory permanently.
  • His rule marked the height of Shaka power in western India.
  • Other options:
    • Bindusara: A Mauryan emperor, ruled in the 3rd century BCE, much earlier.
    • Panduka: Not a known historical Shaka ruler.
    • Chashtana: The grandfather of Rudradaman I and an earlier Shaka ruler, but not ruling during 130–150 CE.

question:
The Kandariya Mahadeva Temple was constructed in 999 A.D. by the king Dhangadeva of _________ dynasty.

SSC MTS 15/05/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• The correct answer is (a) Chandela.
  • The Kandariya Mahadeva Temple, located in Khajuraho, Madhya Pradesh, was constructed around 999 A.D. by King Dhangadeva of the Chandela dynasty.
  • It is the largest and most ornate Hindu temple in the Khajuraho complex, dedicated to Lord Shiva.

Key Features:

  • Built in the Nagara style of architecture, the temple is famous for its intricate carvings, especially the erotic sculptures that reflect the aesthetics of the time.
  • It stands on a high platform (jagati) and consists of a sanctum (garbhagriha), hall (mandapa), and shikhara (spire).
  • The temple symbolises Mount Meru, the mythical source of creation in Hindu cosmology.

Additional Information:

  • The Chandela dynasty ruled in central India from the 9th to the 13th century CE and were great patrons of temple architecture.
  • Other options:
    • Pala dynasty: Flourished in eastern India (mainly Bengal and Bihar), known for Buddhist art.
    • Pallava dynasty: Based in South India, known for Mahabalipuram temples.
    • Chola dynasty: Famous for Dravidian temples like Brihadeshwara in Tamil Nadu.

question:
In the mid-eighth century, Dantidurga, a Rashtrakuta chief, overthrew his Chalukya overlord and performed a ritual literally called a _________.

SSC MTS 16/05/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Golden womb.
  • In the mid-8th century CE, Dantidurga, a Rashtrakuta chief, defeated his Chalukya overlord and established Rashtrakuta rule in the Deccan region.
  • After his victory, he performed the Hiranyagarbha (literally “golden womb”) ritual.

What is the Hiranyagarbha Ritual?

  • The Hiranyagarbha was an ancient Vedic ritual that symbolically recreated the birth of a king.
  • The ritual was performed by Kshatriyas or chiefs who had newly acquired sovereignty or independence.
  • It involved placing the performer in a golden vessel (representing the womb) and symbolically rebirthing him as a true Kshatriya monarch.

Additional Information:

  • This act legitimised the authority of the new king and signified his independent royal status.
  • The Rashtrakutas went on to become a powerful dynasty in Deccan India from the 8th to 10th century CE.
  • Other options:
    • Prarthna Sabha: A 19th-century reformist movement, not a ritual.
    • Horse ride: Possibly alluding to Ashvamedha, but not the correct term here.
    • Subsidiary alliance: A British-era political policy, not a ritual.

question:
The emblem of the Chera Dynasty that controlled the central and northern parts of Kerala and the Kongu region of Tamil Nadu was __________.

SSC MTS 16/05/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• The correct answer is (c) bow and arrow.
  • The Chera Dynasty, one of the three major Tamil dynasties during the Sangam age (along with the Cholas and Pandyas), ruled over central and northern Kerala and parts of western Tamil Nadu, including the Kongu region.
  • Their official emblem or royal insignia was the bow and arrow.

Significance of the Emblem:

  • The bow symbolised military strength, warrior spirit, and the authority of the king.
  • It helped in distinguishing the Cheras from other dynasties like:
    • Cholas, whose emblem was the tiger.
    • Pandyas, whose emblem was the fish.
    • Pallavas often used lion or bull motifs.

Additional Information:

  • The Cheras had trade links with Rome and China, and ports like Muziris were famous.
  • Famous Chera rulers include Senguttuvan, who is associated with the legend of the Kannagi cult and built a temple for her.

question:
Which of the following is NOT part of six schools of Indian Philosophy?

SSC MTS 17/05/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The correct answer is (d) Dravida.
  • The six orthodox schools of Indian philosophy are known as the Shad Darshanas. These are:
    1. Nyaya – focuses on logic and epistemology.
    2. Vaisheshika – deals with atomism and categorisation of reality.
    3. Samkhya – a dualistic philosophy of purusha (spirit) and prakriti (matter).
    4. Yoga – closely aligned with Samkhya, emphasising meditation and discipline (codified by Patanjali).
    5. Purva Mimamsa – focuses on rituals and interpretation of the Vedas.
    6. Vedanta (Uttara Mimamsa) – focuses on metaphysics and the end portion of the Vedas (Upanishads).
  • Dravida is not one of the six classical schools of Indian philosophy. The term “Dravida” typically refers to the Dravidian region or culture of South India and is linguistic or ethnic, not philosophical.

Additional Information:

  • These six schools are considered Astika (orthodox) because they accept the authority of the Vedas.
  • In contrast, Nastika systems like Buddhism, Jainism, and Charvaka reject Vedic authority.

question:
Which among the following rulers adopted the title devaputra?

SSC MTS 17/05/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Kushana.
  • The title "Devaputra", meaning "Son of God", was first adopted by Kanishka, one of the most famous rulers of the Kushana dynasty.
  • The Kushanas ruled parts of Central Asia and northern India during the 1st to 3rd centuries CE.

Significance of the Title "Devaputra":

  • "Devaputra" signified divine status and was likely influenced by Central Asian or Chinese traditions where emperors were considered sons of heaven.
  • This title was prominently used in inscriptions and coins during the Kushana period to assert divine legitimacy and imperial grandeur.

Additional Information:

  • Kanishka the Great (c. 127–150 CE) was the most powerful Kushana ruler and a great patron of Buddhism, under whom the 4th Buddhist Council was held.
  • The Kushana Empire played a key role in the spread of Mahayana Buddhism and in promoting Indo-Greek art and Gandhara sculpture.
  • Other options:
    • Hoyasala: A South Indian dynasty (12th–14th century), known for temple architecture.
    • Chola: A Tamil dynasty known for maritime power and Dravidian temple architecture.
    • Saka: Also ruled in India (Western Kshatrapas), but didn’t use "Devaputra" as a title.
